articles.headline: Why Bill Belichick Fit In So Well, for So Long, in New England
articles.snippet: The head coach of the Patriots, who has parted ways with the team after 24 years, won six Super Bowls with a taciturn approach that rewarded performance over potential.
articles.abstract: The head coach of the Patriots, who has parted ways with the team after 24 years, won six Super Bowls with a taciturn approach that rewarded performance over potential.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is hard to make an impression, and even harder to make history in a place as old and momentous as New England. The measuring stick is so high.

articles.headline: F.A.A. Investigating Whether Boeing 737 Max 9 Conformed to Approved Design
articles.snippet: Regulators are examining whether Boeing complied with safety rules on a plane that lost a fuselage panel while in flight last week.
articles.abstract: Regulators are examining whether Boeing complied with safety rules on a plane that lost a fuselage panel while in flight last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Thursday that it had opened an investigation into whether Boeing failed to ensure that its 737 Max 9 plane was safe and manufactured to match the design approved by the agency.

articles.headline: U.S. Missiles Strike Targets in Yemen Linked to the Houthi Militia
articles.snippet: The American-led strikes came in response to more than two dozen Houthi drone and missile attacks against commercial shipping in the Red Sea since the Israel-Hamas war began.
articles.abstract: The American-led strikes came in response to more than two dozen Houthi drone and missile attacks against commercial shipping in the Red Sea since the Israel-Hamas war began.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States and five of its allies on Thursday carried out military strikes against more than a dozen targets in Yemen controlled by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia, in an expansion of the war in the Middle East that the Biden administration had sought to avoid for the past three months.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Taiwan Party, Reviled by China, Battles to Prove Its Staying Power
articles.snippet: The Democratic Progressive Party has transformed Taiwan into a bastion against Chinese power. Now it is promising a mix of change and continuity.
articles.abstract: The Democratic Progressive Party has transformed Taiwan into a bastion against Chinese power. Now it is promising a mix of change and continuity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly four decades ago, a group of lawyers, intellectuals and activists assembled in a hotel ballroom in Taipei to found an illegal political party dedicated to ending authoritarian rule in Taiwan.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei

articles.headline: The Billionaires Spending a Fortune to Lure Scientists Away From Universities
articles.snippet: Arena BioWorks is promising big paydays to nearly 100 researchers from Harvard, M.I.T. and other prestigious institutions.
articles.abstract: Arena BioWorks is promising big paydays to nearly 100 researchers from Harvard, M.I.T. and other prestigious institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unmarked laboratory stationed between the campuses of Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a splinter group of scientists is hunting for the next billion-dollar drug.

articles.headline: Biggest U.S. Banks Earn Billions, Even After Insurance Bill
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo reported healthy quarterly profits. Citigroup said its ongoing restructuring would result in about 20,000 job cuts.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo reported healthy quarterly profits. Citigroup said its ongoing restructuring would result in about 20,000 job cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nationâ€™s largest banks are churning out profits as interest rates remain high, even though the lenders have had to set aside billions of dollars to replenish a deposit insurance fund that was heavily depleted by a crisis among midsize banks last spring.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Stacy Cowley
